title: Phugoid
text:
A phugoid or fugoid is an aircraft motion in which the vehicle pitches up and climbs, and then pitches down and descends, accompanied by speeding up and slowing down as it goes "downhill" and "uphill". This is one of the basic <a href="aircraft%20dynamic%20modes">flight dynamics modes</a> of an <a href="fixed-wing%20aircraft">aircraft</a> (others include <a href="short%20period">short period</a>, <a href="Aircraft_dynamic_modes%23Roll_subsidence_mode">roll subsidence</a>, <a href="dutch%20roll">dutch roll</a>, and <a href="spiral%20divergence">spiral divergence</a>), and is a classic example of a <a href="positive%20feedback">positive feedback</a> system.
Detailed description.
The phugoid has a nearly constant <a href="angle%20of%20attack">angle of attack</a> but varying <a href="pitch%20%28flight%29">pitch</a>, caused by a repeated exchange of <a href="airspeed">airspeed</a> and <a href="altitude">altitude</a>. It can be excited by an <a href="elevator%20%28aircraft%29">elevator</a> singlet (a short, sharp deflection followed by a return to the centered position) resulting in a <a href="pitch%20%28flight%29">pitch</a> increase with no change in <a href="trim%20tab">trim</a> from the <a href="cruise%20%28flight%29">cruise</a> condition. As speed decays, the nose drops below the horizon. Speed increases, and the nose climbs above the horizon. Periods can vary from under 30 seconds for <a href="light-sport%20aircraft">light aircraft</a> to minutes for <a href="airliner">larger aircraft</a>. <a href="Ultralight%20aviation">Microlight aircraft</a> typically show a phugoid period of 15–25 seconds, and it has been suggested that birds and model airplanes show convergence between the phugoid and short period modes. A classical model for the phugoid period can be simplified to about (0.85 × speed in <a href="knot%20%28unit%29">knots</a>) seconds, but this only really works for larger aircraft. 
Phugoids are often demonstrated to student <a href="aviator">pilot</a>s as an example of the speed stability of the aircraft and the importance of proper trimming. When it occurs, it is considered a nuisance, and in lighter airplanes (typically showing a shorter period) it can be a cause of <a href="pilot-induced%20oscillation">pilot-induced oscillation</a>.
The phugoid, for moderate amplitude, occurs at an effectively constant angle of attack, although in practice the angle of attack actually varies by a few tenths of a degree. This means that the stalling angle of attack is never exceeded, and it is possible (in the <1g section of the cycle) to fly at speeds below the known stalling speed. Free flight models with badly unstable phugoid typically stall or loop, depending on thrust.
An unstable or divergent phugoid is caused, mainly, by a large difference between the incidence angles of the wing and tail. A stable, decreasing phugoid can be attained by building a smaller stabilizer on a longer tail, or, at the expense of pitch and yaw "static" stability, by shifting the center of gravity to the rear.
The term "phugoid" was coined by <a href="Frederick%20W.%20Lanchester">Frederick W. Lanchester</a>, the British aerodynamicist who first characterized the phenomenon. He derived the word from the <a href="Greek%20%28language%29">Greek</a> words and to mean "flight-like" but recognized the diminished appropriateness of the derivation given that meant flight in the sense of "escape" (as in the word "fugitive") rather than vehicle flight.
Aviation accidents.
In 1972, an Aero Transporti Italiani <a href="Fokker%20F-27%20Friendship">Fokker F-27 Friendship</a>, en route from Rome Fiumicino to Foggia, climbing through 13,500 feet, entered an area of poor weather with local thunderstorm activity. At almost 15,000 feet the aircraft suddenly lost 1200 feet of altitude and its speed dropped. It developed phugoid oscillations from which the pilots could not recover. The aircraft struck the ground at a speed of 340 knots. Three crew and fifteen passengers on board were all killed.
In the <a href="1975%20Tan%20Son%20Nhut%20C-5%20accident">1975 Tan Son Nhut C-5 accident</a>, USAF C-5 68-0218 with flight controls damaged by failure of the rear cargo/pressure door, encountered phugoid oscillations while the crew was attempting a return to base, and crash-landed in a rice paddy adjacent to the airport. Of the 328 people on board, 153 died, making it the deadliest accident involving a US military aircraft.
In 1985, <a href="Japan%20Airlines%20Flight%20123">Japan Airlines Flight 123</a> lost all hydraulic controls and its vertical stabiliser, and went into phugoid motion. While the crew were able to maintain near-level flight through the use of engine power, the plane lost height over a mountain range northwest of Tokyo before crashing into <a href="Mount%20Takamagahara">Mount Takamagahara</a>. With 520 deaths, it remains the deadliest single-aircraft disaster in history.
In 1989, <a href="United%20Airlines%20Flight%20232">United Airlines Flight 232</a> suffered an uncontained <a href="turbine%20engine%20failure">engine failure</a> in the #2 (tail) engine, which caused total <a href="hydraulic%20system">hydraulic system</a> failure. The crew flew the aircraft with <a href="aircraft%20engine%20controls">throttle</a> only. Suppressing the phugoid tendency was particularly difficult. The pilots reached <a href="Sioux%20Gateway%20Airport">Sioux Gateway Airport</a> but crashed during the landing attempt. All four cockpit crewmembers (one an assisting DC-10 captain on the flight as a passenger) and a majority of the passengers survived.
Another aircraft that lost all hydraulics was a <a href="DHL%20Aviation">DHL</a> operated <a href="Airbus%20A300B4">Airbus A300B4</a> that was hit by a <a href="surface-to-air%20missile">surface-to-air missile</a> fired by the Iraqi resistance in the <a href="2003%20Baghdad%20DHL%20attempted%20shootdown%20incident">2003 Baghdad DHL attempted shootdown incident</a>. This was the first time that a crew landed an air transport aircraft safely by only adjusting engine thrust.
The 2003 crash of the <a href="Helios%20Prototype%23Crash">Helios solar-powered aircraft</a> was precipitated by reacting to an inappropriately diagnosed phugoid oscillation that ultimately made the aircraft structure exceed design loads.
Chesley "Sully" Sullenberger, Captain of <a href="US%20Airways%20Flight%201549">US Airways Flight 1549</a> that <a href="wiktionary%3Aditch%23Verb">ditched</a> in the <a href="Hudson%20River">Hudson River</a> on January 15, 2009, said in a Google talk that the landing could have been less violent had the anti-phugoid software installed on the <a href="Airbus%20A320-214">Airbus A320-214</a> not prevented him from manually getting maximum lift during the four seconds before water impact.
